messages.messageBody:
Milt-
For the listies;

All-
Same was clearly used on handles and scabbards from earliest times.
In the Edo period presentation skins were mounted in fine brocade and
were cherished gifts.As Gordon has said it was used as decoration on
armour.

Today we can purchase kendo armours with lacquered ray skin
do in a variety of colors. I think the problem with ray skin as
armour is not the climate, after all witness all those handles still
in existance, it is more likely for two reasons I can think of. One
the size of the skins, todays do use two or three skins, which look
great but would be weak at the point of overlap. There was surely a
monster ray in those days that would have done the job with a sigle
skin, even then it would have been a rare creature however. Two wear
and tear, the lacquered do of today can take a lot of abuse from
bamboo shinae but a blade is another story. Initially it would look
great but with the first cut would be scarred and weakened and would
only become uglier with each battle, I am sure someone tried it but
feel it would not have appealed to samurai sensibilites¡Ä

-t
